comment_text:
Yeah it's a CYA move by MS. Same reason they don't ship a telnet client by default. Or why you have to double opt-in for gzip with ASP.NET+IIS.

I'm guessing, like SELinux, what users end up doing is just disabling things completely (or enabling all options) instead of figuring out all the specifics. I understand, no one wants to be responsible for shipping a vulnerability by default, like MS products used to be.

Also see their terrible HTTP.SYS reservation system. Any program can listen on a socket. But if you want to use that socket for HTTP and use the OS-provided functions? Boom, special ACLs apply; enjoy figuring out a special one off utility. Or just run your service as a local admin.
author: MichaelGG
story_title: Microsoft nixes ActiveX add-on technology in new Edge browser
